G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28 (modification of judgments as to care, custody, and maintenance of minor children) and, to the extent applicable, G.L. c. 209C, § 20, the Probate and Family Court retains continuing jurisdiction to modify prior orders relating to legal custody, physical custody, and parenting time upon a showing of a material and substantial change in circumstances and where modification is in the best interests of the child.

G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 20.proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28 (modification of judgments as to care, custody, and maintenance of minor children) and, to the extent applicable, G.L. c. 209C, § 20, the Probate and Family Court retains continuing jurisdiction to modify prior orders relating to legal custody, physical custody, and parenting time upon a showing of a material and substantial change in circumstances and where modification is in the best interests of the child.

G.L. c. 215, \u00a7 6.proposition: COMPLAINT FOR MODIFICATION (G.L. c. 208, § 28; G.L. c. 209C, § 20; G.L. c. 215, § 6)

Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.raw_text: Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001)
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.proposition: Since entry of the 2019 Judgment, there has been a material and substantial change in circumstances affecting the best interests and welfare of the minor child, within the meaning of G.L. c. 208, § 28 and relevant case law, including but not limited to:
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.support_reasoning: The proposition asserts that there *has* been a material and substantial change in circumstances since a specific 2019 judgment. Rosenthal v. Maney does not find a material and substantial change; it holds almost the opposite—relocation and a court‑imposed temporary custody change, by themselves, did not constitute a sufficient material and substantial change under G.L. c. 208, § 28 to justify modifying custody. The case is useful for defining the § 28 standard and emphasizing that a change must be of sufficient magnitude and occur after the prior order, but it does not support the factual assertion that such a change has occurred in another case.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.relevant_excerpt: “A judgment modifying custody must be based on findings grounded in the evidence that, since the date of the prior custody order, there has been a change in circumstances ‘of sufficient magnitude to satisfy the governing principle by which the court must be guided in these cases, namely, whether the transfer of custody will be conducive to the welfare of the [child].’ Fuller v. Fuller, 2 Mass. App. Ct. 372, 376 (1974). ‘The uprooting of a child . . . should be done only for compelling reasons.’”

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).proposition: The paramount consideration in any custody or parenting time determination is the best interests of the child.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly discusses and reaffirms that custody determinations are governed by the “best interests of the child” standard and describes this as the controlling (“touchstone”) principle in Massachusetts custody law. It further notes that ‘the best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern,’ directly aligning with the proposition that the child’s best interests are the paramount consideration in custody and parenting time decisions.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt: “In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry of what is ‘best for the child’ is firmly rooted in American history… The ‘best interests’ standard appeared in our case law at least as early as 1865… It has been adhered to ever since. See, e.g., Blixt v. Blixt… (best interests standard ‘has long been used in Massachusetts to decide issues of custody and visitation’); Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704, 710 (1985) (‘best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern’).”

Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas, 395 Ma.proposition: Since entry of the 2019 Judgment, there has been a material and substantial change in circumstances affecting the best interests and welfare of the minor child, within the meaning of G.L. c. 208, § 28 and relevant case law, including but not limited to:
Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas, 395 Ma.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns the standard for modifying an existing custody judgment under G.L. c. 208, § 28 based on a material and substantial change in circumstances. Yannas v. Frondistou‑Yannas does not address modification under § 28 or the ‘material and substantial change’ requirement; it is an initial divorce and custody/removal decision applying the ‘real advantage’ standard and interpreting G.L. c. 208, § 30. Therefore, it does not provide authority for the claimed proposition about post‑judgment change in circumstances.
Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas, 395 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “The Massachusetts removal statute, G. L. c. 208, § 30 (1984 ed.), provides that ‘[a] minor child of divorced parents who is a native of . . . this commonwealth . . . shall not, if of suitable age to signify his consent, be removed out of this commonwealth without such consent, or, if under that age, without the consent of both parents, unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.’ The words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child (Rubin v. Rubin, 370 Mass. 857 [1976]; Hale v. Hale, supra at 815)…”}

Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.raw_text: Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 734 (1996)
Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.proposition: The parties’ mutual recognition that the existing judgment no longer serves Jacob’s best interests is a significant circumstance for the Court’s consideration.
Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns modification of custody based on a material and substantial change in circumstances and the best interests of the children, but it does not discuss or give weight to any mutual recognition by the parties that an existing judgment no longer serves a child’s best interests. The court focuses on the mother’s rehabilitation, the children’s preferences, expert evidence, and the presumption of keeping siblings together. There is no indication that the parents’ shared view about the prior judgment’s adequacy is treated as a significant circumstance for the court’s consideration.
Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 208, § 28… enables a Probate Court judge, upon finding that ‘a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties has occurred’ to modify an earlier divorce judgment concerning the custody arrangements of minor children, where the modification ‘is necessary in the best interests of the children.’… When determining child custody awards in general, or modifications of custody awards based on changed circumstances, the guiding principle always has been the best interests of the children.”

Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).proposition: As Massachusetts courts have repeatedly recognized, stability and continuity in a child’s life are crucial to the child’s best interests.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).support_reasoning: The opinion focuses on the impact of domestic violence on children and the need for explicit findings about that impact when determining custody, not on the general importance of stability and continuity in a child’s life. While the court mentions the boy is doing well in school and notes existing custody arrangements, it does not articulate or rely on a broader principle that stability and continuity are crucial to a child’s best interests. Thus, it does not serve as authority for the specific proposition cited.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).relevant_excerpt: We agree with the Appeals Court that the judge below “fail[ed] to make detailed and comprehensive findings of fact on the issues of domestic violence and its effect upon the child as well as upon the father’s parenting ability.” … It is well documented that witnessing domestic violence, as well as being one of its victims, has a profound impact on children.

Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010).proposition: Massachusetts appellate decisions confirm that a party seeking modification of a custody or parenting time judgment bears the burden of demonstrating (1) a material and substantial change in circumstances since entry of the prior judgment, and (2) that the proposed modification is in the child’s best interests.
Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010).support_reasoning: The concurring opinion in Smith v. McDonald focuses on statutory interpretation of the paternity statute (G.L. c. 209C) and the improper application of removal/relocation principles (the Yannas ‘real advantage’ test). It does not discuss the standards or burden of proof for modification of an existing custody or parenting-time judgment, nor does it articulate the two-part ‘material and substantial change’ plus ‘best interests’ test. Accordingly, it does not provide authority for the specific modification proposition stated.
Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010).relevant_excerpt: The court concludes, and I concur, that the judge had no authority to issue an order during the pendency of litigation for the child (and hence the mother) to move back to Massachusetts. See ante at 550. As the court acknowledges, a person having sole parental rights is “free to move with the child wherever she wishe[s].” Id. at 549-550. As a matter of law, it should make no difference to a parent’s freedom to relocate that another party subsequently files to establish parental rights. See G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a), (b).

Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..raw_text: Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 899 (1981)
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Massachusetts appellate decisions confirm that a party seeking modification of a custody or parenting time judgment bears the burden of demonstrating (1) a material and substantial change in circumstances since entry of the prior judgment, and (2) that the proposed modification is in the child’s best interests.
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion deals with the proper criteria for an initial custody determination on appeal from a divorce judgment, not with a post‑judgment modification proceeding. It discusses that custody decisions must be based on the child’s welfare and best interests, but it does not address (or allocate) the burden of proof for modifying an existing custody or parenting time judgment, nor does it mention the requirement of a material and substantial change in circumstances since a prior judgment.
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “In a proceeding involving custody of a child, ‘as matter of law and as matter of humanity’ ‘[t]he governing principle by which the court must be guided in deciding the issues raised is the welfare of the child’ (emphasis supplied)… This court will not sustain a custody award unless all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child have been weighed. The weight ascribed to the respective factors is to be measured solely in terms of its effect on the welfare or well being of the child.”

Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219 (1998).proposition: The paramount consideration in any custody or parenting time determination is the best interests of the child.
Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219 (1998).support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly frames the judge’s task, once parental unfitness is found, as determining which placement is in the child’s best interests, and treats that standard as the controlling, discretionary inquiry in custody/adoption decisions. The court also repeatedly describes the statutory and common-law framework in terms of the child’s best interests, confirming that this is the paramount consideration in custody or parenting time (placement) determinations.
Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219 (1998).relevant_excerpt: “Once the judge concluded that parental unfitness was established, he correctly determined that the central question was whether it was in Hugo’s best interests to remain with his foster mother or to be transferred to the care and custody of his aunt. G. L. c. 210, § 3 (c). The ‘best interests of a child’ is a question that presents the trial judge ‘with a classic example of a discretionary decision.’ … [M]uch must be left to the trial judge’s experience and judgment.”

Guardianship of Estelle, 70 Mass. App. C.raw_text: Guardianship of Estelle, 70 Mass. App. Ct. 575 (2007)
Guardianship of Estelle, 70 Mass. App. C.proposition: As Massachusetts courts have repeatedly recognized, stability and continuity in a child’s life are crucial to the child’s best interests.
Guardianship of Estelle, 70 Mass. App. C.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly recognizes that the impact of disrupting an established placement and bonded relationship must be weighed in determining parental fitness and a child’s best interests. The court emphasizes the need to consider the child’s attachment to current caretakers, the trauma of removal, and the harm that a transfer of custody might cause, which implicitly underscores the importance of stability and continuity in the child’s life. Although the case does not use the exact phrase “stability and continuity,” its reasoning relies on those concepts as crucial to the best-interests analysis.
Guardianship of Estelle, 70 Mass. App. C.relevant_excerpt: “Here, a key factual question for resolution is whether the father is fit to parent this particular child in light of the lengthy period during which she has been raised by, and has bonded with, the uncle and aunt… Thus, there must be attention to the effect on this child of whatever separation from the uncle and aunt would come about if there is a transfer to the father, including whether the father is prepared and able to cope adequately with the child’s trauma that would inevitably accompany her separation from the uncle and aunt.”

Care & Protection of Emily, 433 Mass. 56.proposition: Jacob’s expressed desire for overnight visits with Father, while not controlling, is a relevant and appropriate factor given his age and maturity.
Care & Protection of Emily, 433 Mass. 56.support_reasoning: The opinion excerpt is a criminal homicide/self‑defense case and does not involve child custody, visitation, or consideration of a child’s expressed preferences. It nowhere discusses a child named Jacob, overnight visits, or the legal standard for weighing a child’s wishes based on age and maturity. Accordingly, it does not provide authority for the proposition about Jacob’s desire for overnight visits with his father.
Care & Protection of Emily, 433 Mass. 56.relevant_excerpt: No excerpt in this opinion addresses a child’s preferences, custody, or visitation; the case concerns jury instructions on manslaughter, provocation, and self-defense in a murder prosecution.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 31.proposition: G.L. c. 208, § 31 sets forth that custody determinations shall be made in accordance with the best interests of the child, and recognizes that children should have frequent and continuing contact with both parents when consistent with their best interests.

M.G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 31.proposition: This balance is consistent with the policies underlying G.L. c. 208, §§ 28, 31 and the caselaw favoring frequent and continuing contact with both parents when safe and appropriate.
